abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Liuzhou Environment
            Management Project for China were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: like sewerage service, solid waste
            management requires adequate operations and revenues to
            build an effective refuse collection system, and commitment
            from city managers to set up adequate operation policies, in
            particular when landfills are far from the city center, thus
            requiring transfer stations. The Liuzhou Municipal
            Government (LMG) intended to improve the efficiency of its
            solid waste management operations by introducing both
            institutional reforms and cost recovery policies. The
            project provided Technical Assistance (TA) to Liuzhou
            Environmental Sanitation Department (ESD) to analyze various
            institutional options to achieve this objective. Targeting
            multiple cities with complex components can result in
            implementation delays, particularly when project management
            offices (PMOs) and implementing agencies lack staff
            experience in Bank operations. This project involved only
            one city and funded a limited number of high priority
            investments and programs. TA was also provided to the PMO
            and the project implementing agencies to strengthen their
            capacity to implement the project.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Liuzhou Environment Management
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Liuzhou
            Environment Management Project for China is to assist
            Liuzhou Municipality of Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous region in
            improving the municipality's environmental conditions
            by investing in wastewater treatment facilities, industrial
            pollution control, municipal sanitation services and solid
            waste services and management. The total project costs have
            increased from US$205.6 million to US$216.13 million due to
            substantial depreciation of US dollars against RMB, as the
            exchange rate is reduced from 8.2868 at appraisal to 6.6275
            at end of 2010. The reallocation is necessary to fully fund
            the remaining ongoing works after recent price escalations
            increased contract costs. In order to ensure that the
            project management unit and project implementing units have
            sufficient time to submit final withdrawal applications
            after the Loan closing date, a four month grace period,
            through October 31, 2011, is added.

display_title.display_title:
China - Liuzhou Environment
            Management Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

6332372.majtheme: Urban development,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Liuzhou Environment Management
            Project for China aims to improve the environmental
            conditions in Liuzhou through improved wastewater treatment,
            sanitation control, solid waste management, and industrial
            wastewater pollution control. The project has the following
            five components: Component 1) will help develop a
            comprehensive wastewater collection and treatment system in
            Liuzhou. The project will: (a) invest in about 73km of
            sewers, 76 km of interceptors, seven pumping stations, and
            four wastewater treatment plants (WWTP); (b) rehabilitate
            about 42 km of drains; and (c) support operations in the
            recently established autonomous wastewater management
            company. Component 2) will construct approximately 62 public
            toilets and procure 30 portable toilets, two mobile toilets,
            and six sanitation trucks. Component 3) will construct one
            municipal solid waste transfer station, 42 waste collection
            stations, and procure needed waste hauling trucks and
            associated vehicles to transport waste to the second city
            landfill. Component 4) will help Liuzhou Municipal
            Government (LMG) implement comprehensive industrial
            wastewater pollution control policies and programs.
            Component 5) includes technical assistance (TA) to: help
            implement the project's wastewater, solid waste
            management, and municipal sanitation components.
